componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the Realty Income 3Q 2015 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. And at this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Janeen Bedard. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, all, for joining us today for Realty Income third quarter 2015 operating results conference call. Discussing our results will be John Case, Chief Executive Officer; Paul Meurer, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer; and Sumit Roy, Chief Operat
componenttext:
Thank you, all, for joining us today for Realty Income third quarter 2015 operating results conference call. Discussing our results will be John Case, Chief Executive Officer; Paul Meurer, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer; and Sumit Roy, Chief Operating Officer and Chief Investment Officer. During this conference call, we will make certain statements that may be considered to be forward-looking statements under federal securities law. The company's actual future results may differ significantly from the matters discussed in any forward-looking statements. David disclose in greater detail the factors that may cause such differences in the company's Form 10-Q. 
I will now turn the call over to our CEO, John Case.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Janeen, and welcome to our call today. We're pleased with another solid quarter and our position as we move into the end of the year and the beginning of 2016. Our AFFO per share annual growth during the quarter was 9.4% to a record quarterly amou
componenttext:
Thanks, Janeen, and welcome to our call today. We're pleased with another solid quarter and our position as we move into the end of the year and the beginning of 2016. Our AFFO per share annual growth during the quarter was 9.4% to a record quarterly amount of $0.70. As announced in yesterday's press release, we are raising and tightening the range of our AFFO per share guidance for 2015 from $2.69 to $2.73 to the new range of $2.72 to $2.74 given the company's strong year-to-date performance and the continued scalability of the business platform. A very high percentage of our revenue continues to floor [ph] to the bottom line. We are also introducing our 2016 AFFO per share guidance of $2.85 to $2.90, representing annual per share growth of 4.4% to 6.2%. 
I'll now hand it over to Paul to provide additional detail on our financial results.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. As usual, I will provide a few highlights on our financial statements for the quarter and begin with the income statement. Total revenue increased 9.8% for the quarter. This increase reflects our growth primarily from new acquisitions over t
componenttext:
Thanks, John. As usual, I will provide a few highlights on our financial statements for the quarter and begin with the income statement. Total revenue increased 9.8% for the quarter. This increase reflects our growth primarily from new acquisitions over the past year, as well as same-store rent growth. Our annualized rental revenue at September 30 was approximately $992 million. Interest expense increased in the quarter to $64 million. This increase was due to the $250 million 12 year notes we issued in September of last year and a $250 million term loan issued at the end of last quarter, as well as lower amortization of mortgage premiums as our outstanding mortgage balance continues to decline. We also did recognize a noncash loss of approximately $5.2 million on interest rate swaps during the quarter. As a reminder, we entered into an interest rate swap on the term loan issued in June which led to the larger noncash loss this quarter. On a related note, our coverage ratios both remain strong, with interest coverage at 4.2x and fixed charge coverage at 3.8x. Both of these metrics are pro forma for the paydown of the credit facility balance with proceeds from our common stock offering earlier this month. General and administrative, or G&A, expenses were approximately $10.9 million for the quarter. Included in G&A expense this quarter is approximately $70,000 in acquisition costs, and a reminder that we include these acquisition costs in our calculation of both FFO and AFFO. 
Year-to-date, our G&A as a percentage of total rental and other revenues is only 5%. We estimate that 5% will remain our approximate win [ph] rate for G&A for the remainder of the year as efficiencies in our business model continue to drive improving EBITDA margin. Property expenses, which are not reimbursed by tenants, totaled $3.4 million for the quarter. Year-to-date, our property expenses as a percentage of total rental and other revenues is only  1.5%. We estimate this  1.5% will remain our approximately run rate for property expenses for the remainder of the year as these expenses continued to come in lower this year, with lower portfolio vacancy, faster releasing of vacant properties, lower property churn premiums and fewer onetime maintenance expenses. Provisions of impairment of approximately $3.9 million for the quarter included impairments on 1 property held-for-sale, 1 held for investment and 2 sold properties. Gain on sales were approximately $6.2 million in the quarter, and just a reminder, we do not include property sales gains in our FFO or AFFO. Adjusted funds from operations, or AFFO were the actual cash we have available for distribution of dividend were $0.70 per share for the quarter, a 9.4% increase versus a year ago. We again increased our cash flow dividend this quarter and now increased to a current annualized amount of $2.286 per share. 
Briefly turning to the balance sheet, we continue to maintain our conservative capital structure. In September, we established an ATM, or at-the-market equity distribution program, to offer and sell up to 12 million shares, giving us the ability to issue equity capital on an opportunistic basis. Through quarter end, we have not yet issued any equity through this program. During the quarter, we did raise $152 million of equity capital through our direct stock purchase plan. And earlier this month, we raised $517 million in net proceeds in a common stock offering. We use the proceeds to pay down all outstanding borrowings on our $2 billion unsecured revolving credit facility. Our bonds, which are all unsecured and fixed rate, continue to be rated Baa1 BBB+ at a weighted average maturity of 6.5 years. We again did not assume any mortgages during the quarter. We did pay off some of maturities, so our outstanding net mortgage net at quarter end decreased to approximately $695 million. Not including our credit facility is only variable rate debt exposure we have is only just $15.5 million of mortgage debt. And our overall debt maturity schedule remains in very good shape, with only $2 million of mortgages and $150 million of bonds coming due for the balance of this year and our maturity schedule is well-laddered thereafter. Currently our debt to total market capitalization is approximately 28% and our preferred stock outstanding is only 2% of our capital structure. And our debt-to-EBITDA ratio after the equity offering is approximately 5.1x. 
Now let me turn the call back over to John, who will give you more background on these results.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. I'll begin with an overview of the portfolio, which continues to perform well. Occupancy, based on the number of properties, was 98.3%, a 10 basis points improvement from last quarter. At the end of the quarter, we had 74 properties that are
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. I'll begin with an overview of the portfolio, which continues to perform well. Occupancy, based on the number of properties, was 98.3%, a 10 basis points improvement from last quarter. At the end of the quarter, we had 74 properties that are available for lease out of 4,473 properties in our portfolio. Economic occupancy was 99.3% and occupancy based on square footage was 99% increasing 10 basis points and 20 basis points respectively from last quarter. We continue to see an active leasing environment and expect our occupancy to remain around current levels for the end of the year. We had leases expire on 95 properties during the quarter and we re-leased 97 properties. Additionally, 5 vacant properties were sold during the quarter, so our vacant property count decreased by 7 properties relative to last quarter. 86 properties were re-leased to existing tenants and 11 were re-leased to new tenants. We recaptured 99% of expiring rents without any spending on tenant improvements as is typical for us.  We have a lot of experience in this area of our business. Over the last 20 years, we have re-leased or sold more than 2,000 properties with expired leases. 
Our same-store rent increased 1.1% during the quarter and 1.3% year-to-date. We expect annual same-store rent growth to be approximately 1.3% this year and next year. As many of you know, the timing of our rent increases are irregular and will vary from quarter-to-quarter. 90% of our leases have contractual rent increases, so we remain pleased with the growth we are able to achieve from our properties. Approximately 75% of our investment-grade leases have rental rate growth that averages about 1.3%. Our portfolio continues to be diversified by tenant, industry, geography and to a certain extent, property type. At the end of the third quarter, our properties were leased to 236 commercial tenants, operating in 47 different industries located in 49 states and Puerto Rico. Our diversification contributes to the stability of our cash flow. 79% of our rental revenue is from our traditional retail properties. The largest component outside of retail is industrial properties at 13% of rental revenue. There was really not much movement in the composition of our top tenants and industries during the third quarter. Walgreens remains our largest tenant at 7% of rental revenue; and drugstores remain our largest industry at 11% of rental revenue. 
We continue to have excellent credit quality in the portfolio, with 44% of our rental revenue generated from investment-grade tenants. This dropped from 48% last quarter due to the completion of Dollar Tree's acquisition of Family Dollar in July, which is now rated BB. This percentage will continue to fluctuate and will be positively impacted by 2 pending acquisitions of our noninvestment grade rated tenants by investment grade-rated tenants.  Store level performance of our retail tenants remains sound. Our weighted average rent coverage ratio for the retail properties continues to be 2.6x on a [indiscernible] basis and [indiscernible] is also 2.6x. 
Moving on to acquisitions, during the quarter, we completed $124 million in acquisitions and we continue to see a high volume of sourced acquisition opportunities. Year-to-date, we have sourced $24 billion in acquisition opportunities and we are on track for our second most active year ever for source volume. We remain disciplined in our investment strategy, acquiring less than 5% or $1.1 billion of the amount sourced year-to-date. A large portion of the acquisitions completed so far this year occur earlier than we had originally expected, which has had a positive impact on our 2015 earnings growth. We continue to expect approximately $1.25 billion in acquisitions volume for 2015. Our initial guidance for 2016 acquisitions is approximately $750 million, which consequently reflects our typical flow business and does not account for any large-scale transaction. 
I'll hand it over to Sumit to discuss our acquisitions and its positions. Sumit?

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. During the third quarter of 2015, we invested $124 million in 47 properties located in 22 states, at an average initial cash cap rate of 7% and with the weighted average lease term of 10.9 years. On a revenue basis, 35% of total acquisiti
componenttext:
Thank you, John. During the third quarter of 2015, we invested $124 million in 47 properties located in 22 states, at an average initial cash cap rate of 7% and with the weighted average lease term of 10.9 years. On a revenue basis, 35% of total acquisitions are from investment-grade tenants. 52% of the revenues are generated from retail and 48% are from industrial. These assets are leased to 18 different tenants in 13 different industries. Some of the most significant industries represented our transportation services, motor vehicle dealerships and quick service restaurants. We closed 10 independent transactions in the third quarter and the average investment of property was approximately $2.6 million. Year-to-date 2015, we invested $1.1 billion in 195 properties located in 36 states at an average initial cash cap rate of 6.5% and with a weighted average lease term of 16.7 years. On a revenue basis, 50% of total acquisitions are from investment-grade tenants, 87% of the revenues are generated from retail and 13% are from industrial. These assets are leased to 35 different tenants in 18 industries. Some of the most significant industries represented are health and fitness, drugstores and quick service restaurants. Of the 35 independent transactions closed year-to-date, 3 transactions were above $50 million [ph]. 
The transaction flow continues to remain healthy. We sourced more than $4 billion in the third quarter. Year-to-date, we have sourced more than $24 billion in potential transaction opportunities. Of these opportunities, 62% of the volume sourced were portfolios and 38% or approximately $9 billion were one-off assets. Investment grade opportunities represented 26% [ph] for the third quarter. Of the $124 million in acquisitions closed in the third quarter, 77% were one-off transactions. We continue to capitalize on our extensive industry relationships developed over our 46-year operating history. As to pricing, cap rates remain flat in the third quarter, with investment-grade properties trading from around 5% to high 6% cap rate range and noninvestment grade properties trading from high 5% to low 8% cap rate range. 
Our disposition program remained active. During the quarter, we sold 8 properties for $21.5 million at a net cash cap rate of 7.2% and realized an unlevered IRR of 14.2%. This brings us to 22 properties sold year-to-date for approximately $52 million at a net cash cap rate of 7.6% and realized an unlevered IRR of 13%. Our investment spreads relative to our weighted average cost of capital were healthy, averaging 212 basis points in the third quarter which were above our historical average spreads. We define investment spreads as initial cash yield less our nominal first-year weighted average cost of capital. 
In conclusion, we remain confident of reaching our acquisition and dispositions goals of approximately $1.25 billion and $65 million respectively for 2015. With that, I'd like to hand it back to John.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sumit. We've been active in the capital during the year to meet our capital needs. Year-to-date, we have raised approximately $1.2 billion in equity capital at an average per share price of approximately $48.50. This includes the 517 equity offeri
componenttext:
Thanks, Sumit. We've been active in the capital during the year to meet our capital needs. Year-to-date, we have raised approximately $1.2 billion in equity capital at an average per share price of approximately $48.50. This includes the 517 equity offering earlier this month that Paul mentioned. Our balance sheet is in excellent shape, with plenty of liquidity and financial flexibility. Our sector leading cost of capital continues to allow us to drive earnings growth while investing in high-quality assets. We increased the dividends paid this quarter by 4% on a year-over-year basis. We have increased our dividend every year since the company's listing in 1994, growing the dividend at a compound average annual rate of just under 5%. Our AFFO payout ratio in the third quarter was 81.4%, which is a level we are quite comfortable with. 
To wrap it up, our portfolio is performing well and we are pleased with where we stand as we head into the end of the year and into 2016. We continue to realize the efficiencies associated with our size and the economies of scale of our net lease business. We believe our EBITDA margin is the highest in the sector at 93%. We continue to see a high volume of acquisition opportunities and our balance sheet is in outstanding condition with exceptional financial flexibility to fund future growth opportunities. 
At this time, we would like to open it up to questions. Operator?

componenttext: Great, just a last sort of bigger picture question, with the Walgreens righted merger, any potential store closures given overlaps that may be required as through the FTC and just competition? And then do you expect the management team to maybe look at any real estate monetizations?

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me take a crack at that one. Obviously, we view the merger as a net positive for the company. We believe it's a credit and value-enhancing event, Realty Income is likely to improve the credit quality and definitely will improve the credit quality o
componenttext: So let me take a crack at that one. Obviously, we view the merger as a net positive for the company. We believe it's a credit and value-enhancing event, Realty Income is likely to improve the credit quality and definitely will improve the credit quality of the portfolio with an additional 1.8%, at least, of our rent becoming investment-grade rated. S&P affirmed the BBB rating yesterday, but did put them, put Walgreens, on negative outlook which is normal in such situations as you recall when we bought our [indiscernible] negative, well S&P rates to see how you execute and finance the transaction. There will be no impact on our revenues as a result of any possible divestitures. What Walgreens will have the contractual obligation to pay the rent through the term. [indiscernible] market over the last 2 days have estimated that anywhere from 0 to 400 stores would be closed, so that's quite a range. But on our Walgreens assets, we have an average lease term of 13 years. On our RiteAid assets, we have an average lease terms of 9 yes. And there's really little property overlap in the 2 portfolios. Of the 58 RiteAid locations we own, 15 of those within a 2-mile radius of a Walgreens store, and the average lease term needs to be about 8 years. So we feel really good about that. And we're pleased with both companies' performance. We'll take our, depending on acquisitions, between now and the end of next year, it will take exposure or our percentage of revenues from Walgreens up to somewhere in the high 8s probably, right around 9%. But if we're going to have a tenant, that's a little higher than we typically like the tenant concentrations to be. But if we're going to have a tenant there, we like that it's Walgreens. And from a drugstore industry perspective, there will be no change in our exposure. It will still be at around 11%.

componenttext: Yes, as you know, the acquisitions competition and amounts vary quite a bit from quarter-to-quarter. componenttext: That's very fair. We're going to have our third best year ever in terms of completed acquisitions. We're going to have our second best year ever in terms of sourced acquisition opportunities. So that's a lot of momentum in the business. And I wouldn't characterize this as declining momentum. I'd characterize this as typical fluctuations quarter-to-quarter in acquisition volume. We're achieving excellent results on our sales and these are on our nonstrategic properties. Some of them have issues associated with them, perhaps credit, real estate issues, coverage issues, industry issues and some we're just selling because we have maybe some concentration issues and I want to reduce our concentration levels. But the fact that we're able to sell these year-to-date at a 7.7 cap rate, 7.2 cap rate in the third quarter and achieve an IRR unlevered of 14%, I think it kind of shows you the quality of our portfolio because we're calling off the lower quality assets in general. So I hope that shows the market that we really got a strong portfolio if that's where the properties we want just goes up for trading.

componenttext: Yes, it's actually our cheapest form of raising equity, closer to a 1% average cost there of issuance compared to on ATM, which is going to be more like 1.5% to 2% and then your overnight offering is going to be more than that obviously. So it is a product that we remain utilizing with largely with existing shareholders as well as part of that, their ability to reinvest. But not to any significant amount. As John mentioned, we'll be doing a little bit of that activity in quarter going forward but in larger equity raises would be dependent upon acquisition volume.

componenttext: It's really a function of timing. We remain, Paul, obviously, I want to talk about sort of philosophy. We are comfortable with the company. 2/3 equity, 1/3 debt. headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, all, for joining us today for Realty Income's third quarter 2015 operating results conference call. Discussing our results will be John Case, Chief Executive Officer; Paul Meurer, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer; and Sumit Roy, Chief Oper
componenttext:
Thank you, all, for joining us today for Realty Income's third quarter 2015 operating results conference call. Discussing our results will be John Case, Chief Executive Officer; Paul Meurer, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer; and Sumit Roy, Chief Operating Officer and Chief Investment Officer. During this conference call, we will make certain statements that may be considered to be forward-looking statements under federal securities law. The company's actual future results may differ significantly from the matters discussed in any forward-looking statements. We will disclose in greater detail the factors that may cause such differences in the company's Form 10-Q. 
I will now turn the call over to our CEO, John Case.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Janeen, and welcome to our call today. We're pleased with another solid quarter and our position as we move into the end of the year and the beginning of 2016. Our AFFO per share annual growth during the quarter was 9.4% to a record quarterly amou
componenttext:
Thanks, Janeen, and welcome to our call today. We're pleased with another solid quarter and our position as we move into the end of the year and the beginning of 2016. Our AFFO per share annual growth during the quarter was 9.4% to a record quarterly amount of $0.70. As announced in yesterday's press release, we are raising and tightening the range of our AFFO per share guidance for 2015 from $2.69 to $2.73 to the new range of $2.72 to $2.74 given the company's strong year-to-date performance and the continued scalability of our business platform. A very high percentage of our revenue continues to floor to the bottom line. We are also introducing our 2016 AFFO per share guidance of $2.85 to $2.90, representing annual per share growth of 4.4% to 6.2%. 
I'll now hand it over to Paul to provide additional detail on our financial results.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. As usual, I will provide a few highlights on our financial statements for the quarter and begin with the income statement. Total revenue increased 9.8% for the quarter. This increase reflects our growth primarily from new acquisitions over t
componenttext:
Thanks, John. As usual, I will provide a few highlights on our financial statements for the quarter and begin with the income statement. Total revenue increased 9.8% for the quarter. This increase reflects our growth primarily from new acquisitions over the past year, as well as same-store rent growth. Our annualized rental revenue at September 30 was approximately $992 million. Interest expense increased in the quarter to $64 million. This increase was due to the $250 million 12-year notes we issued in September of last year and a $250 million term loan issued at the end of last quarter, as well as lower amortization of mortgage premiums, as our outstanding mortgage balance continues to decline. We also did recognize a noncash loss of approximately $5.2 million on interest rate swaps during the quarter. As a reminder, we entered into an interest rate swap on the new term loan issued in June, which led to the larger noncash loss this quarter. On a related note, our coverage ratios both remained strong, with interest coverage at 4.2x and fixed charge coverage at 3.8x. Both of these metrics are pro forma for the paydown of the credit facility balance, with proceeds from our common stock offering earlier this month. General and administrative or  A, expenses were approximately $10.9 million for the quarter. Included in G&A expense this quarter is approximately $70,000 in acquisition cost, and a reminder that we include these acquisition cost in our calculation of both FFO and AFFO. 
Year-to-date, our G&A as a percentage of total rental and other revenues is only 5%. We estimate that 5% will remain our approximate run rate for G&A for the remainder of the year, as efficiencies in our business model continue to drive improving EBITDA margin. Property expenses, which are not reimbursed by tenants, totaled $3.4 million for the quarter. Year-to-date, our property expenses as a percentage of total rental and other revenues is only 1.5%. We estimate this 1.5% will remain our approximate run rate for property expenses for the remainder of the year, as these expenses have continued to come in lower this year, with lower portfolio vacancy, faster releasing of vacant properties, lower property churn premiums and fewer onetime maintenance expenses. Provisions for impairment of approximately $3.9 million during the quarter included impairments on 1 property held-for-sale, 1 held for investment and 2 sold properties. Gain on sales were approximately $6.2 million in the quarter, and just a reminder, we do not include property sales gains in our FFO or AFFO. Adjusted funds from operations or AFFO or the actual cash we have available for distribution of dividend was $0.70 per share for the quarter, a 9.4% increase versus a year ago. We again increased our cash monthly dividend this quarter and it now equates to a current annualized amount of $2.286 per share. 
Briefly turning to the balance sheet. We've continued to maintain our conservative capital structure. In September, we established an ATM or at-the-market equity distribution program to offer and sell up to 12 million shares, giving us the ability to issue equity capital on an opportunistic basis. Through quarter end, we have not yet issued any equity through this program. During the quarter, we did raise $152 million of equity capital through our direct stock purchase plan. And earlier this month, we raised $517 million in net proceeds in a common stock offering. We used the proceeds to pay down all outstanding borrowings on our $2 billion unsecured revolving credit facility. Our bonds, which are all unsecured and fixed rate, and continue to be rated Baa1 BBB+ at a weighted average maturity of 6.5 years. We again did not assume any mortgages during the quarter. We did pay off some of the maturities, so our outstanding net mortgage debt at quarter end decreased to approximately $695 million. Not including our credit facility, the only variable rate debt exposure we have is only just $15.5 million of mortgage debt. And our overall debt maturity schedule remains in very good shape, with only $2 million of mortgages and $150 million of bonds coming due for the balance of this year, and our maturity schedule is well-laddered thereafter. Currently our debt to total market capitalization is approximately 28% and our preferred stock outstanding is only 2% of our capital structure, and our debt-to-EBITDA ratio after the equity offering is approximately 5.1x. 
Now let me turn the call back over to John, who will give you more background on these results.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. I'll begin with an overview of the portfolio, which continues to perform well. Occupancy, based on the number of properties, was 98.3%, a 10 basis points improvement from last quarter. At the end of the quarter, we had 74 properties that are
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. I'll begin with an overview of the portfolio, which continues to perform well. Occupancy, based on the number of properties, was 98.3%, a 10 basis points improvement from last quarter. At the end of the quarter, we had 74 properties that are available for lease out of 4,473 properties in our portfolio. Economic occupancy was 99.3%, and occupancy based on square footage was 99%, increasing 10 basis points and 20 basis points respectively from last quarter. We continue to see an active leasing environment, and expect our occupancy to remain around current levels through the end of the year. We had leases expire on 95 properties during the quarter, and we re-leased 97 properties. Additionally, 5 vacant properties were sold during the quarter, so our vacant property count decreased by 7 properties relative to last quarter. 86 properties were re-leased to existing tenants and 11 were re-leased to new tenants. We recaptured 99% of expiring rents without any spending on tenant improvements as is typical for us.  We have a lot of experience in this area of our business. Over the last 20 years, we have re-leased or sold more than 2,000 properties with expired leases. 
Our same-store rent increased 1.1% during the quarter and 1.3% year-to-date. We expect annual same-store rent growth to be approximately 1.3% this year and next year. As many of you know, the timing of our rent increases are irregular and will vary from quarter-to-quarter. 90% of our leases have contractual rent increases, so we remain pleased with the growth we are able to achieve from our properties. Approximately 75% of our investment-grade leases have rental rate growth that averages about 1.3%. Our portfolio continues to be diversified by tenant, industry, geography, and to a certain extent, property type. At the end of the third quarter, our properties were leased to 236 commercial tenants, operating in 47 different industries located in 49 states and Puerto Rico. Our diversification contributes to the stability of our cash flow. 79% of our rental revenue is from our traditional retail properties. The largest component outside of retail is industrial properties at 13% of rental revenue. There was really not much movement in the composition of our top tenants and industries during the third quarter. Walgreens remains our largest tenant at 7% of rental revenue; and drugstores remain our largest industry at 11% of rental revenue. 
We continue to have excellent credit quality in the portfolio, with 44% of our rental revenue generated from investment-grade tenants. This dropped from 48% last quarter due to the completion of Dollar Tree's acquisition of Family Dollar in July, which is now rated BB. This percentage will continue to fluctuate and will be positively impacted by 2 pending acquisitions of our non-investment grade rated tenants by investment grade-rated tenants.  Store level performance of our retail tenants remains sound. Our weighted average rent coverage ratio for the retail properties continues to be 2.6x on a four-wall basis and the median is also 2.6x. 
Moving on to acquisitions. During the quarter, we completed $124 million in acquisitions, and we continue to see a high volume of sourced acquisition opportunities. Year-to-date, we have sourced $24 billion in acquisition opportunities, and we are on track for our second most active year ever for source volume. We remain disciplined in our investment strategy, acquiring less than 5% or $1.1 billion of the amount sourced year-to-date. A large portion of the acquisitions completed so far this year occurred earlier than we had originally expected, which has had a positive impact on our 2015 earnings growth. We continue to expect approximately $1.25 billion in acquisitions volume for 2015. Our initial guidance for 2016 acquisitions is approximately $750 million, which principally reflects our typical flow business, and does not account for any large-scale transactions.
I'll hand it over to Sumit to discuss our acquisitions and dispositions. Sumit?

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. During the third quarter of 2015, we invested $124 million in 47 properties located in 22 states at an average initial cash cap rate of 7%, and with a weighted average lease term of 10.9 years. On a revenue basis, 35% of total acquisition
componenttext:
Thank you, John. During the third quarter of 2015, we invested $124 million in 47 properties located in 22 states at an average initial cash cap rate of 7%, and with a weighted average lease term of 10.9 years. On a revenue basis, 35% of total acquisitions are from investment-grade tenants. 52% of the revenues are generated from retail and 48% are from industrial. These assets are leased to 18 different tenants in 13 industries. Some of the most significant industries represented our transportation services, motor vehicle dealerships and quick service restaurants. We closed 10 independent transactions in the third quarter, and the average investment for property was approximately $2.6 million. Year-to-date 2015, we invested $1.1 billion in 195 properties located in 36 states at an average initial cash cap rate of 6.5% and with a weighted average lease term of 16.7 years. On a revenue basis, 50% of total acquisitions are from investment-grade tenants. 87% of the revenues are generated from retail and 13% are from industrial. These assets are leased to 35 different tenants in 18 industries. Some of the most significant industries represented are health and fitness, drugstores and quick service restaurants. Of the 35 independent transactions closed year-to-date, 3 transactions were above $50 million.
The transaction flow continues to remain healthy. We sourced more than $4 billion in the third quarter. Year-to-date, we've sourced more than $24 billion in potential transaction opportunities. Of these opportunities, 62% of the volume sourced were portfolios and 38% or approximately $9 billion were one-off assets. Investment grade opportunities represented 26% for the third quarter. Of the $124 million in acquisitions closed in the third quarter, 77% were one-off transactions. We continue to capitalize on our extensive industry relationships developed over our 46-year operating history. As to pricing, cap rates remain flat in the third quarter, with investment-grade properties trading from around 5% to high 6% cap rate range, and non-investment grade properties trading from high 5% to low 8% cap rate range. 
Our disposition program remained active. During the quarter, we sold 8 properties for $21.5 million at a net cash cap rate of 7.2%, and realized an unlevered IRR of 14.2%. This brings us to 22 properties sold year-to-date or approximately $52 million at a net cash cap rate of 7.6% and realized an unlevered IRR of 13%. Our investment spreads relative to our weighted average cost of capital were healthy, averaging 212 basis points in the third quarter which were above our historical average spreads. We define investment spreads as initial cash yield less our nominal first-year weighted average cost of capital. 
In conclusion, we remain confident of reaching our acquisition and dispositions goals of approximately $1.25 billion and $65 million respectively for 2015. With that, I'd like to hand it back to John.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sumit. We've been active in the capital market spread during the year to meet our capital needs. Year-to-date, we have raised approximately $1.2 billion in equity capital at an average per share price of approximately $48.50. This includes the $51
componenttext:
Thanks, Sumit. We've been active in the capital market spread during the year to meet our capital needs. Year-to-date, we have raised approximately $1.2 billion in equity capital at an average per share price of approximately $48.50. This includes the $517 million equity offering earlier this month that Paul mentioned. Our balance sheet is in excellent shape, with plenty of liquidity and financial flexibility. Our sector leading cost of capital continues to allow us to drive earnings growth, while investing in high-quality assets. We increased the dividends paid this quarter by 4% on a year-over-year basis. We have increased our dividend every year since the company's listing in 1994, growing the dividend at a compound average annual rate of just under 5%. Our AFFO payout ratio in the third quarter was 81.4%, which is a level we are quite comfortable with. 
To wrap it up, our portfolio is performing well and we are pleased with where we stand as we head into the end of the year and into 2016. We continue to realize the efficiencies associated with our size and the economies of scale of our net lease business. We believe our EBITDA margin is the highest in the sector at 93%. We continue to see a high volume of acquisition opportunities, and our balance sheet is in outstanding condition with exceptional financial flexibility to fund future growth opportunities. 
At this time, we would like to open it up for questions. Operator?

componenttext: So the large delta with regard to FFO is a result of the swap and the impact that has on FFO, and you don't see that line in AFFO. So -- and that's very difficult to predict, the forward curve. So you see that it did have a $4 million impact this year. It could go up or down from there, but we wanted to make sure we locked a range broad enough to handle, what we thought would be reasonable in terms of movement there.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, just a last sort of more bigger picture question, with the Walgreens Rite Aid merger, any thoughts on potential store closures, given overlaps with the -- that maybe required as per the FTC and just competition? And then do you expect the managemen
componenttext: Great, just a last sort of more bigger picture question, with the Walgreens Rite Aid merger, any thoughts on potential store closures, given overlaps with the -- that maybe required as per the FTC and just competition? And then do you expect the management team to maybe look at any real estate monetizations?

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me take a crack at that one. Obviously, we view the merger as a net positive for the company. We believe it's a credit and value-enhancing event. Realty Income is likely to improve the credit quality. It definitely will improve the credit quality o
componenttext: So let me take a crack at that one. Obviously, we view the merger as a net positive for the company. We believe it's a credit and value-enhancing event. Realty Income is likely to improve the credit quality. It definitely will improve the credit quality of the portfolio with an additional 1.8%, at least, of our rent becoming investment-grade rated. S&P affirmed the BBB rating yesterday, but did put them -- put Walgreens, on a negative outlook, which is normal in its M&A situations, as you recall, when we bought our TI. We have put on a negative outlook. Well, S&P rates to see how you execute and finance the transaction. There'll be no impact on our revenue as a result of the -- any possible divestitures. Walgreens will have the contractual obligation to pay the rent through the term. The pungence in the market over the last 2 days have estimated that anywhere from 0 to 400 stores would be closed, so that's quite a range. But on our Walgreens assets, we have an average lease term of 13 years. On our RiteAid assets, we have an average lease terms of 9 yes, and there's really little property overlap in the 2 portfolios. Of the 58 RiteAid locations we own, 15 of those are within a 2-mile radius of a Walgreens store, and the average lease term, I believe, is about 8 years. So we feel really good about that, and we're pleased with both companies' performance. It will take our -- depending on acquisitions, between now and the end of next year, it will take exposure or our percentage of revenues from Walgreens up to somewhere in the high 8s probably, right around 9%. But if we're going to have a tenant, that's a little higher than we typically like the tenant concentrations to be. But if we're going to have a tenant there, we like that it's Walgreens. And from a drugstore industry perspective, there'll be no change in our exposure. We'll still be at around 11%.

When you look at what we've done year-to-date, 87% has been retail, and we continue to have 79% of our revenues come from retail properties. So you're not going to see that number change much. So it's a bit of an aberration, but it's just relevant here in the third quarter.

componenttext: Okay, and then I guess just -- and you kind of touched on this in those remarks, but just given the deceleration in kind of the pipeline again, obviously, some lumpier larger deals in the second quarter, you still feel pretty good just about where your pipeline stands right now, and there's not likely any meaningful change in the composition of it. componenttext: That's very fair. We're going to have our third best year ever in terms of completed acquisitions. We're going to have our second best year ever in terms of sourced acquisition opportunities. So that's a lot of momentum in the business, and I wouldn't characterize this as declining momentum. I'd characterize this as typical fluctuations quarter-to-quarter in acquisition volume. So again, it's very difficult to predict, but we're certainly comfortable with where the business is and the momentum we have.

componenttext: Yes, it's pretty stable at 1.1%, and not everything on there we will end up selling. So we are, as you've heard, looking at ramping up by dispositions a bit from what we have originally planned for this year, from $50 million to $65 million. We're achieving excellent results on our sales, and these are at our nonstrategic properties. Some of them have issues associated with them, perhaps, credit, real estate issues, coverage issues, industry issues, and some we're just selling because we have maybe some concentration issues, and we don't want to reduce our concentration levels. But the fact that we're able to sell these year-to-date at a 7.7 cap rate, a 7.2 cap rate in the third quarter and achieve an IRR unlevered of 14%, I think, kind of shows you the quality of our portfolio because we're calling off the lower quality assets in general. So I hope that shows the market that we really got a strong portfolio if that's where the properties we want to dispose of the trading.

But I think there's it's -- yes, there's no major changes, I think, is safe to say, and we'll continue to execute at the levels we executed at this year.

componenttext: Okay, no problem. And for Paul, when you look at your cost of equity, certainly, if the overnight market's open to you, you have the ATM in place, although you've untapped it. headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Yes, it's actually our cheapest form of raising equity, closer to a 1% average cost there of issuance compared to an ATM, which is going to be more like 1.5% to 2%, and then your overnight offerings are going to be more than that obviously. So it is a product that will remain -- utilizing with largely with existing shareholders, as well as part of that, their ability to reinvest, but not to any significant amount. And as John mentioned, we'll be doing a little bit of that activity in the quarter going forward, but any larger equity raises would be just dependent upon acquisition volume.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, if you look at the market today, there's about a 50 to 75 basis points differential between where our RiteAid and where our Walgreens will trade. componenttext: Did you have -- did you pull back at all, I guess, on your acquisition activity due to the softness that we saw in both the debt and equity markets in the third quarter?

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we didn't. I mean, this is just a function of the opportunities we saw that met our investment parameters and there's a lot, as I said, volatility from quarter-to-quarter and the amount and quality of acquisition opportunities we see. So we're very pl
componenttext: No, we didn't. I mean, this is just a function of the opportunities we saw that met our investment parameters and there's a lot, as I said, volatility from quarter-to-quarter and the amount and quality of acquisition opportunities we see. So we're very pleased with where our own balance sheet is. We've got a lot of financial flexibility and significant liquidity. So we did not specifically pullback on the acquisitions activity as a result of some of the volatility we saw in the marketplace.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. And then -- and I'm curious guys on, Paul, on the bonds that you're doing or that you might do. I mean, are these going to get bigger, do you think? I mean, I think of you guys having $5 billion of debt roughly, that kind of thing in 10-y
componenttext: Okay, all right. And then -- and I'm curious guys on, Paul, on the bonds that you're doing or that you might do. I mean, are these going to get bigger, do you think? I mean, I think of you guys having $5 billion of debt roughly, that kind of thing in 10-year ladder maturity, some thinking of larger bond transactions when you do -- the last couple seems smaller, and I'm wondering are you going to carry more in your line of credit? Are you going to do a bigger bond transaction, going forward, you think?

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: They may get bigger at times, of course. As we get larger as a company, you could certainly see larger issuances. Certainly, the minimum of $250 million to be indexed, I suppose, something we would always pursue. But at points in time, when you go to issu
componenttext: They may get bigger at times, of course. As we get larger as a company, you could certainly see larger issuances. Certainly, the minimum of $250 million to be indexed, I suppose, something we would always pursue. But at points in time, when you go to issue the bond, it really depends on what your needs are at that particular time. And if you don't have, say, a $500 million cash need at that moment, you're not going to issue $500 million bond. That's happened a few times. And furthermore, we haven't quite seen any pricing improvement having a slightly larger offering size. If we would start to understand that you'd get a little bit better pricing from the dead investors for a larger liquid offering, that's something we may even pursue more.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's been an interesting comment that [indiscernible], and certainly, something we've studied, Reg, and that is do you get paid for larger, more liquid offerings, and certainly, a lot of our fixed income investors would prefer those and say that you
componenttext: Yes. It's been an interesting comment that [indiscernible], and certainly, something we've studied, Reg, and that is do you get paid for larger, more liquid offerings, and certainly, a lot of our fixed income investors would prefer those and say that you do. But when you look at the case studies available and we work with our bankers, you don't see a pricing advantage. But that being said, larger company, as Paul said, doing larger transactions, I think you'll see our average transaction certainly grow beyond $250 million, and you can see some $0.5 million bond deals in our future.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Is there a negative to go in the market to often like if you had to do $1 billion, and you did $4 million on each quarter of $250 million, is that a negative?
componenttext: Okay. Is there a negative to go in the market to often like if you had to do $1 billion, and you did $4 million on each quarter of $250 million, is that a negative?

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: If that was the scenario, for example, I think the preference would be to do, say, 2 $500 million rather than 4 $250 million as your fixed income investors would prefer the larger liquidity in each particular issuance. But you can't always project what yo
componenttext: If that was the scenario, for example, I think the preference would be to do, say, 2 $500 million rather than 4 $250 million as your fixed income investors would prefer the larger liquidity in each particular issuance. But you can't always project what your needs are going to be to stay with the bond market, the acquisition deal flow timing, that sort of thing, of course.

componenttext: Okay. And then as you look forward, that remaining investment on Page 15 of $58 million, how should we think about the time frame over which that's going to occur? And then I guess on top of that, how many more we might add on a quarterly basis, new properties to the list?

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as of right now, as it says on Page 15, we've got $58 million of additional commitments to spend. And based on the pipeline, the next quarter, we don't expect to add any new additional development, so that number should remain pretty static. Of co
componenttext: Yes. So as of right now, as it says on Page 15, we've got $58 million of additional commitments to spend. And based on the pipeline, the next quarter, we don't expect to add any new additional development, so that number should remain pretty static. Of course, we're not going to spend off of that $58 million, so you'd expect that to go down. In the event we do hear back from some tenants, et cetera, with regards to redevelopment, et cetera, that's the only reason why that $58 million will change.

componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you guys could touch a little bit on the operating expenses and why that continues to kind of come in below your expectations. I mean, your recovery ratio seems to be fairly high relative to what it has been historically.
componenttext: I was wondering if you guys could touch a little bit on the operating expenses and why that continues to kind of come in below your expectations. I mean, your recovery ratio seems to be fairly high relative to what it has been historically.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Yes, with regard to -- are you talking about with regard to G&A or property or both?

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Frankly, both. But just on the property operating expenses, 1.5%, that's a lot lower than what it has been, historically.
componenttext: Frankly, both. But just on the property operating expenses, 1.5%, that's a lot lower than what it has been, historically.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we've realized probably $4 million to $5 million in savings, did fewer defaults this year, and even lower vacancy, I think, in an improved stronger portfolio. It's reducing our property expense obligations the company is responsible for. We're als
componenttext: Yes, so we've realized probably $4 million to $5 million in savings, did fewer defaults this year, and even lower vacancy, I think, in an improved stronger portfolio. It's reducing our property expense obligations the company is responsible for. We're also helping drive that as much quicker resolution of lease rollovers. We improved our property insurance premiums as well, as we become a larger company with scale. And on the G&A front, if you go back and look at kind of our headcount, about 3 years ago, we had some pretty significant additions in headcount, and then a year after that, they were fairly significant, and we are really positioning the company to handle the growth that we had anticipated, and we had hoped we would continue, and those earnings have fallen each year. We put really skillful people in place, I think, and have a more efficient organizational structure and more efficient systems, which allow us to have better G&A margins. So there's some other items related to that, but that's what's it's really about. So when we budgeted this year, we budgeted for some headcount that we did not end up having to add to the company, which helped us come in at $2 million to $4 million below where we thought we were going to be on that item. So that's what really is driving both property expenses and G&A expense margins.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just kind of curious on the -- Paul, on the leverage at 5.1x net debt-to-EBITDA, looking at my numbers, it seems to be the lowest you've been in quite some time. Is this -- is there any type of concerted effort on your part or on the company's part to
componenttext: So just kind of curious on the -- Paul, on the leverage at 5.1x net debt-to-EBITDA, looking at my numbers, it seems to be the lowest you've been in quite some time. Is this -- is there any type of concerted effort on your part or on the company's part to kind of maintain a lower-level leverage than you have maybe over the last couple of years? Or it's just simply a function of kind of timing?

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's really a function of timing. We remain -- I'm not Paul, obviously, but I want to talk about this sort of philosophy. We're comfortable with the company, 2/3 equity, 1/3 debt. Right now, we're closer to 70%, 71% equity today, a little more conservativ
componenttext: It's really a function of timing. We remain -- I'm not Paul, obviously, but I want to talk about this sort of philosophy. We're comfortable with the company, 2/3 equity, 1/3 debt. Right now, we're closer to 70%, 71% equity today, a little more conservatively capitalized in that. We saw an attractive opportunity to execute an overnight offering at pricing that would be attractive and highly accretive through our investments, and we've had a use for the proceeds and we wanted to position the balance sheet in a matter very clean and liquid and ready to fund our anticipated acquisitions going into 2016. So this is not a level -- this is not a new level that really represents the change in leverage policy for us, Dan. It's just a result of a recent large equity offering.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And is there any type of -- is there any seasonality to maybe '16's acquisitions? Do you think it will be more front-end loaded or more back-end-loaded or kind of ratably over the year?
componenttext: Okay, understood. And is there any type of -- is there any seasonality to maybe '16's acquisitions? Do you think it will be more front-end loaded or more back-end-loaded or kind of ratably over the year?

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wish we could answer that question. This year, we thought they were going to be more back-end-loaded given a couple of larger portfolios we were working on, and hearing when those tenants wanted to close and then 2 changed. And all of a sudden, we went
componenttext: I wish we could answer that question. This year, we thought they were going to be more back-end-loaded given a couple of larger portfolios we were working on, and hearing when those tenants wanted to close and then 2 changed. And all of a sudden, we went from expecting a back-end-loaded acquisitions year that switch to front-end loaded acquisition year. It's really difficult to predict. So in our model right now, we just have that $750 million at -- based on a pro rata structure throughout the year, and it won't happen that way. There'll be quarters where there's big numbers, and there'll be quarters where there are small numbers, and unfortunately, I'm not smart enough to tell you which ones -- which quarters are going to be big and which quarters are going to be small.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And then from a portfolio standpoint, has the private letter ruling that's kind of gone away in the IRS or SEC, whoever it is, has kind of said they're going to stay away from this stuff or this Opco/Propco type of structure that people
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then from a portfolio standpoint, has the private letter ruling that's kind of gone away in the IRS or SEC, whoever it is, has kind of said they're going to stay away from this stuff or this Opco/Propco type of structure that people have done. Have you seen any kind of increasing inbound calls as -- to you guys because of kind of this change in policy from the government?

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We continue to be involved in a number of conversations on that front. We did interpret that as a net positive because if you are going to monetize real estate, and the IRS is taking that stance, then sale leaseback financing and transactions with compani
componenttext: We continue to be involved in a number of conversations on that front. We did interpret that as a net positive because if you are going to monetize real estate, and the IRS is taking that stance, then sale leaseback financing and transactions with companies like ours is the appropriate and best execution, we believe. There hasn't been a sea wave of additional discussions, no, but there's a slight uptick, and we continue to be fairly optimistic that one or two of those will quit and be significant.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttextpreview: John, just kind of following up on a couple of last questions. On the philosophy side, I guess, I was wondering if you might be able to remind us kind of what your thoughts are in terms of max category exposure that you would be willing to take and sort o
componenttext: John, just kind of following up on a couple of last questions. On the philosophy side, I guess, I was wondering if you might be able to remind us kind of what your thoughts are in terms of max category exposure that you would be willing to take and sort of max single tenant exposure that you guys would take.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Chris. So what we've said on single tenants is that we're comfortable in sort of in the mid-single-digit range, so call that kind of up to 7%. Under certain circumstances, will we be comfortable going above that. But over the long run, we'd like to
componenttext: Sure, Chris. So what we've said on single tenants is that we're comfortable in sort of in the mid-single-digit range, so call that kind of up to 7%. Under certain circumstances, will we be comfortable going above that. But over the long run, we'd like to manage our exposure back down because the diversification is highly important to us and our strategy. So you'll see that we kind of -- so I mean, when the Walgreens RiteAid transaction closes, we'll have a tenant that's in the upper-8s in terms of percentage of revenues. So that will be a tenant that we look very, very closely at, and in terms of increasing our exposure. In fact, we would not want to increase the exposure in -- it was just something exceptional in terms of an incredibly attractive investment opportunity, and then we have discussions with our team here, and with our board to see if we even wanted to do that. On the industry side, it's always been kind of in the lower double digits, in the sort of 10% to 12% range, and we want to remain in that area, and right now, we're in that area, but the diversification is something that we think is important in our type of business.

componenttext: We received so many opportunities and the investments that fall within our investment parameters today. That's not something we're really looking at. componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the Realty Income 3Q 2015 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. And at this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Janeen Bedard. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, all, for joining us today for Realty Income's third quarter 2015 operating results conference call. Discussing our results will be John Case, Chief Executive Officer; Paul Meurer, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer; and Sumit Roy, Chief Oper
componenttext:
Thank you, all, for joining us today for Realty Income's third quarter 2015 operating results conference call. Discussing our results will be John Case, Chief Executive Officer; Paul Meurer, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer; and Sumit Roy, Chief Operating Officer and Chief Investment Officer. During this conference call, we will make certain statements that may be considered to be forward-looking statements under federal securities law. The company's actual future results may differ significantly from the matters discussed in any forward-looking statements. We will disclose in greater detail the factors that may cause such differences in the company's Form 10-Q. 
I will now turn the call over to our CEO, John Case.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Janeen, and welcome to our call today. We're pleased with another solid quarter and our position as we move into the end of the year and the beginning of 2016. Our AFFO per share annual growth during the quarter was 9.4% to a record quarterly amou
componenttext:
Thanks, Janeen, and welcome to our call today. We're pleased with another solid quarter and our position as we move into the end of the year and the beginning of 2016. Our AFFO per share annual growth during the quarter was 9.4% to a record quarterly amount of $0.70. As announced in yesterday's press release, we are raising and tightening the range of our AFFO per share guidance for 2015 from $2.69 to $2.73 to the new range of $2.72 to $2.74 given the company's strong year-to-date performance and the continued scalability of our business platform. A very high percentage of our revenue continues to flow to the bottom line. We are also introducing our 2016 AFFO per share guidance of $2.85 to $2.90, representing annual per share growth of 4.4% to 6.2%. 
I'll now hand it over to Paul to provide additional detail on our financial results.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. As usual, I will provide a few highlights on our financial statements for the quarter and begin with the income statement. Total revenue increased 9.8% for the quarter. This increase reflects our growth primarily from new acquisitions over t
componenttext:
Thanks, John. As usual, I will provide a few highlights on our financial statements for the quarter and begin with the income statement. Total revenue increased 9.8% for the quarter. This increase reflects our growth primarily from new acquisitions over the past year, as well as same-store rent growth. Our annualized rental revenue at September 30 was approximately $992 million. Interest expense increased in the quarter to $64 million. This increase was due to the $250 million 12-year notes we issued in September of last year and a $250 million term loan issued at the end of last quarter, as well as lower amortization of mortgage premiums, as our outstanding mortgage balance continues to decline. We also did recognize a noncash loss of approximately $5.2 million on interest rate swaps during the quarter. As a reminder, we entered into an interest rate swap on the new term loan issued in June, which led to the larger noncash loss this quarter. On a related note, our coverage ratios both remained strong, with interest coverage at 4.2x and fixed charge coverage at 3.8x. Both of these metrics are pro forma for the paydown of the credit facility balance, with proceeds from our common stock offering earlier this month. General and administrative, or G&A, expenses were approximately $10.9 million for the quarter. Included in G&A expense this quarter is approximately $70,000 in acquisition cost, and a reminder that we include these acquisition costs in our calculation of both FFO and AFFO. 
Year-to-date, our G&A as a percentage of total rental and other revenues is only 5%. We estimate that 5% will remain our approximate run rate for G&A for the remainder of the year, as efficiencies in our business model continue to drive improving EBITDA margin. Property expenses, which are not reimbursed by tenants, totaled $3.4 million for the quarter. Year-to-date, our property expenses as a percentage of total rental and other revenues is only 1.5%. We estimate this 1.5% will remain our approximate run rate for property expenses for the remainder of the year, as these expenses have continued to come in lower this year, with lower portfolio vacancy, faster re-leasing of vacant properties, lower property insurance premiums and fewer onetime maintenance expenses. Provisions for impairment of approximately $3.9 million during the quarter included impairments on 1 property held-for-sale, 1 held for investment and 2 sold properties. Gain on sales were approximately $6.2 million in the quarter, and just a reminder, we do not include property sales gains in our FFO or AFFO. Adjusted funds from operations or AFFO or the actual cash we have available for distribution of dividend was $0.70 per share for the quarter, a 9.4% increase versus a year ago. We again increased our cash monthly dividend this quarter and it now equates to a current annualized amount of $2.286 per share. 
Briefly turning to the balance sheet. We've continued to maintain our conservative capital structure. In September, we established an ATM or at-the-market equity distribution program to offer and sell up to 12 million shares, giving us the ability to issue equity capital on an opportunistic basis. Through quarter end, we have not yet issued any equity through this program. During the quarter, we did raise $152 million of equity capital through our direct stock purchase plan. And earlier this month, we raised $517 million in net proceeds in a common stock offering. We used the proceeds to pay down all outstanding borrowings on our $2 billion unsecured revolving credit facility. Our bonds, which are all unsecured and fixed rate, and continue to be rated Baa1 BBB+ had a weighted average maturity of 6.5 years. We again did not assume any mortgages during the quarter. We did pay off some of the maturities, so our outstanding net mortgage debt at quarter end decreased to approximately $695 million. Not including our credit facility, the only variable rate debt exposure we have is on just $15.5 million of mortgage debt. And our overall debt maturity schedule remains in very good shape, with only $2 million of mortgages and $150 million of bonds coming due for the balance of this year, and our maturity schedule is well-laddered thereafter. Currently, our debt to total market capitalization is approximately 28% and our preferred stock outstanding is only 2% of our capital structure, and our debt-to-EBITDA ratio after the equity offering is approximately 5.1x. 
Now let me turn the call back over to John, who will give you more background on these results.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. I'll begin with an overview of the portfolio, which continues to perform well. Occupancy, based on the number of properties, was 98.3%, a 10 basis points improvement from last quarter. At the end of the quarter, we had 74 properties that are
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. I'll begin with an overview of the portfolio, which continues to perform well. Occupancy, based on the number of properties, was 98.3%, a 10 basis points improvement from last quarter. At the end of the quarter, we had 74 properties that are available for lease out of 4,473 properties in our portfolio. Economic occupancy was 99.3%, and occupancy based on square footage was 99%, increasing 10 basis points and 20 basis points, respectively, from last quarter. We continue to see an active leasing environment, and expect our occupancy to remain around current levels through the end of the year. We had leases expire on 95 properties during the quarter, and we re-leased 97 properties. Additionally, 5 vacant properties were sold during the quarter, so our vacant property count decreased by 7 properties relative to last quarter. 86 properties were re-leased to existing tenants and 11 were re-leased to new tenants. We recaptured 99% of expiring rents without any spending on tenant improvements as is typical for us.  We have a lot of experience in this area of our business. Over the last 20 years, we have re-leased or sold more than 2,000 properties with expired leases. 
Our same-store rent increased 1.1% during the quarter and 1.3% year-to-date. We expect annual same-store rent growth to be approximately 1.3% this year and next year. As many of you know, the timing of our rent increases are irregular and will vary from quarter-to-quarter. 90% of our leases have contractual rent increases, so we remain pleased with the growth we are able to achieve from our properties. Approximately 75% of our investment-grade leases have rental rate growth that averages about 1.3%. Our portfolio continues to be diversified by tenant, industry, geography, and to a certain extent, property type. At the end of the third quarter, our properties were leased to 236 commercial tenants operating in 47 different industries located in 49 states and Puerto Rico. Our diversification contributes to the stability of our cash flow. 79% of our rental revenue is from our traditional retail properties. The largest component outside of retail is industrial properties at 13% of rental revenue. There was really not much movement in the composition of our top tenants and industries during the third quarter. Walgreens remains our largest tenant at 7% of rental revenue; and drugstores remain our largest industry at 11% of rental revenue. 
We continue to have excellent credit quality in the portfolio, with 44% of our rental revenue generated from investment-grade tenants. This dropped from 48% last quarter due to the completion of Dollar Tree's acquisition of Family Dollar in July, which is now rated BB. This percentage will continue to fluctuate and will be positively impacted by 2 pending acquisitions of our non-investment grade-rated tenants by investment grade-rated tenants.  Store level performance of our retail tenants remains sound. Our weighted average rent coverage ratio for the retail properties continues to be 2.6x on a four-wall basis and the median is also 2.6x. 
Moving on to acquisitions. During the quarter, we completed $124 million in acquisitions, and we continue to see a high volume of sourced acquisition opportunities. Year-to-date, we have sourced $24 billion in acquisition opportunities, and we are on track for our second most active year ever for source volume. We remain disciplined in our investment strategy, acquiring less than 5% or $1.1 billion of the amount sourced year-to-date. A large portion of the acquisitions completed so far this year occurred earlier than we had originally expected, which has had a positive impact on our 2015 earnings growth. We continue to expect approximately $1.25 billion in acquisitions volume for 2015. Our initial guidance for 2016 acquisitions is approximately $750 million, which principally reflects our typical flow business, and does not account for any large-scale transactions.
I'll hand it over to Sumit to discuss our acquisitions and dispositions. Sumit?

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. During the third quarter of 2015, we invested $124 million in 47 properties located in 22 states at an average initial cash cap rate of 7%, and with a weighted average lease term of 10.9 years. On a revenue basis, 35% of total acquisition
componenttext:
Thank you, John. During the third quarter of 2015, we invested $124 million in 47 properties located in 22 states at an average initial cash cap rate of 7%, and with a weighted average lease term of 10.9 years. On a revenue basis, 35% of total acquisitions are from investment-grade tenants. 52% of the revenues are generated from retail and 48% are from industrial. These assets are leased to 18 different tenants in 13 industries. Some of the most significant industries represented our transportation services, motor vehicle dealerships and quick service restaurants. We closed 10 independent transactions in the third quarter, and the average investment for property was approximately $2.6 million. Year-to-date 2015, we invested $1.1 billion in 195 properties located in 36 states at an average initial cash cap rate of 6.5% and with a weighted average lease term of 16.7 years. On a revenue basis, 50% of total acquisitions are from investment-grade tenants. 87% of the revenues are generated from retail and 13% are from industrial. These assets are leased to 35 different tenants in 18 industries. Some of the most significant industries represented are health and fitness, drugstores and quick service restaurants. Of the 35 independent transactions closed year-to-date, 3 transactions were above $50 million.
The transaction flow continues to remain healthy. We sourced more than $4 billion in the third quarter. Year-to-date, we've sourced more than $24 billion in potential transaction opportunities. Of these opportunities, 62% of the volume sourced were portfolios and 38% or approximately $9 billion were one-off assets. Investment-grade opportunities represented 26% for the third quarter. Of the $124 million in acquisitions closed in the third quarter, 77% were one-off transactions. We continue to capitalize on our extensive industry relationships developed over our 46-year operating history. As to pricing, cap rates remain flat in the third quarter, with investment-grade properties trading from around 5% to high 6% cap rate range, and non-investment grade properties trading from high 5% to low 8% cap rate range. 
Our disposition program remained active. During the quarter, we sold 8 properties for $21.5 million at a net cash cap rate of 7.2%, and realized an unlevered IRR of 14.2%. This brings us to 22 properties sold year-to-date or approximately $52 million at a net cash cap rate of 7.6% and realized an unlevered IRR of 13%. Our investment spreads relative to our weighted average cost of capital were healthy, averaging 212 basis points in the third quarter which were above our historical average spreads. We define investment spreads as initial cash yield less our nominal first-year weighted average cost of capital. 
In conclusion, we remain confident of reaching our acquisition and dispositions goals of approximately $1.25 billion and $65 million respectively for 2015. With that, I'd like to hand it back to John.

headline: Realty Income Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sumit. We've been active in the capital market spread during the year to meet our capital needs. Year-to-date, we have raised approximately $1.2 billion in equity capital at an average per share price of approximately $48.50. This includes the $51
componenttext:
Thanks, Sumit. We've been active in the capital market spread during the year to meet our capital needs. Year-to-date, we have raised approximately $1.2 billion in equity capital at an average per share price of approximately $48.50. This includes the $517 million equity offering earlier this month that Paul mentioned. Our balance sheet is in excellent shape, with plenty of liquidity and financial flexibility. Our sector leading cost of capital continues to allow us to drive earnings growth, while investing in high-quality assets. We increased the dividends paid this quarter by 4% on a year-over-year basis. We have increased our dividend every year since the company's listing in 1994, growing the dividend at a compound average annual rate of just under 5%. Our AFFO payout ratio in the third quarter was 81.4%, which is a level we are quite comfortable with. 
To wrap it up, our portfolio is performing well and we are pleased with where we stand as we head into the end of the year and into 2016. We continue to realize the efficiencies associated with our size and the economies of scale of our net lease business. We believe our EBITDA margin is the highest in the sector at 93%. We continue to see a high volume of acquisition opportunities, and our balance sheet is in outstanding condition with exceptional financial flexibility to fund future growth opportunities. 
At this time, we would like to open it up for questions. Operator?

componenttext: So the large delta with regard to FFO is a result of the swap and the impact that has on FFO, and you don't see that line in AFFO. It could go up or down from there, but we wanted to make sure we left a range broad enough to handle, what we thought would be reasonable in terms of movement there.
